posts.name: system
posts.cooked:
The latest updates made the dark theme more of a grey which kinda kills a lot of the whole amoled power savings idea.

Can we either have the ‚Äúdark theme‚Äù be black again or have a third option for ‚Äúblack theme‚Äù?

Thanks, love the app!

posts.name: Kyelbek
posts.cooked:
+1
Also I want to move my post which I posted wrongly on GitHub and join it to yours:
‚ÄúSo latest update made dark theme really dark instead of black. Conversation colours were changed from bright ones to darker ones. I know this is a really minor problem but this new dark theme looks really ugly on amoled screens and is inpractical on these. I would like to see black theme back as third option. There should be also setting to change these new darker contacts colours to brighter back or just expand current colour palette with brighter colours that we have seen in older versions. I don‚Äôt think that this is a big deal for you to make it.
If you really started to care about aesthetics of the app (you shown this with last updates after a long time) then give us some options to customize Signal a little instead of forcing us to use these new appearances.
I know that I can install older apk but the worst thing about this is that my ROM doesn‚Äôt have support of installing downgraded apk‚Äôs without deleting current versions. I need to sacriface current keys and convos in order to go back.‚Äù

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
kyelbek:

I need to sacriface current keys and convos in order to go back.‚Äù

You could restore a backup and get the keys back along with the messages. However, if you use the official apk it would give you only a temporary window of use because those apk‚Äôs expire after 90 days.

posts.name: bluevox.47
posts.cooked:
I think it has to do with Google‚Äôs guidelines for developing Android apps. I am talking about Material Design. Take a look at the dark mode in Google News, YouTube, Messages or Google Authenticator. All of these applications do not have a ‚Äòtruly black‚Äô dark theme.

I liked the previous version of dark mode more, but I think it‚Äôs more a matter of habit.

posts.name: Kyelbek
posts.cooked:
Good to know that I could back my keys and messages, too bad that these apks expiring now but it‚Äôs nice safety measure btw.
I‚Äôm also glad that they care about making Signal look consistent because it‚Äôs simply a nice move and I think that makes Android look more complete, however‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think that taking away choice from us is a good practice. Especially if something existed before but it‚Äôs gone now. We‚Äôre not talking about adding some background png‚Äôs which impacts a lot on memory consumption but something simple which is limited to adding few lines to actual code. I‚Äôm pretty sure that it looks really good on LCD panel but not on AMOLED because it‚Äôs foggy there and ugly, especially at night with this new and sad colour palette. Same goes for LCD‚Äôs where black theme looks meh imho.
Also I don‚Äôt use google apps a lot except for YouTube which I‚Äôve got with true black theme so I don‚Äôt really care much about google approach.
All I‚Äôm asking is to bring back true black theme as third option and eventually add an ability to switch between brighter(old) and darker conversations colour palette. I‚Äôm sure there are more people who will agree with me.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
kyelbek:

too bad that these apks expiring now

They do so since the TextSecure 2.3 or 2.4 (I would have to look it up) days. The apk‚Äôs before that don‚Äôt expire but they work only with sms messages, if you want to encrypt sms I‚Äôd rather advice Silence (that can run alongside Signal).

posts.name: Kyelbek
posts.cooked: Didn‚Äôt know that. I‚Äôm staying always up to date with Signal because I trust them and I know that they don‚Äôt screw anything up. There are always pros rather than cons with new versions of apk. I used Silence (SMSSecure) before Signal but I was texting a lot that time and my service provider was bottlenecking me sometimes for sending too much messages (Free SMS plan). I prefer Signal because it‚Äôs equivalent to iMessage allowing to send bigger data to other users with end-to-end encryption. Also having multiple apps for same thing is painful.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
The last time it was an issue for everyone was the jump from 3.16.0 to 3.16.1, where the only change was the version number to prevent the apk to expire: Commits ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Android ¬∑ GitHub

I use Silence as well, to have a fallback when I have no internet access for whatever reason. But since I don‚Äôt have a free sms plan I use it purely as a last resort.

That still doesn‚Äôt justify it though. I choose to have this beautiful AMOLED screen specifically so that I can have dark modes with true blacks and not shimmering gray backgrounds. Those should be reserved for LCDs. This practice is just not taking advantage of AMOLED technology, which is disappointing.

posts.name: Kyelbek
posts.cooked: I would like to add that every next day we are seeing more and more OLED screen phones being rolled out to the market.

posts.cooked:
There is a pull request for an OLED/black theme on github right now. Maybe it gets merged.

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

OLED friendly dark theme

signalapp:master ‚Üê dkopec91:DarkThemeOled
opened 08:15PM - 18 Dec 18 UTC
dkopec91
+43 -2

### First time contributor checklist - [x] I have read [how to contribute](ht‚Ä¶tps://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) to this project - [x] I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://whispersystems.org/cla/) ### Contributor checklist - [x] I am following the [Code Style Guidelines](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/wiki/Code-Style-Guidelines) - [x] I have tested my contribution on these devices: * Lenovo P2, Android 7.0 * Virtual device, Nexus 5X API 25, Android 7.1.1 - [x] My contribution is fully baked and ready to be merged as is - [x] I ensure that all the open issues my contribution fixes are mentioned in the commit message of my first commit using the `Fixes #1234` [syntax](https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-via-commit-messages/) ---------- ### Description Adds additional OLED friendly theme, which uses real black instead of dark gray. It's a feature rather than a fix, but it has been mentioned here as an issue multiple times (#8376 #8304 #8261), and it has been requested on community forum.

From my point of view the current dark theme should be changed as well, if this pull request is merged because it is really dark and too similar to a black theme. Maybe we can go the Google dark theme way? (see Google contacts and phone). I really like the greys there because they are easy on the eyes. For that reason I use Google apps instead of the Oneplus ones on my phone.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
The previous PR made the mistake of adding a new theme, instead of modifying and testing the existing Dark theme.

The existing dark theme should be modified so it backgrounds are completely black instead of #121212. contrast should be thoroughly tested thought the app. I think a PR like that stands a good change of getting merged.

snowburne:

The latest updates made the dark theme more of a grey which kinda kills a lot of the whole amoled power savings idea.

FYI:

XDA Developers ‚Äì 27 Jun 19

No, "AMOLED Black" Does NOT Save More Battery Than Dark Gray

Does using dark gray in a Dark Mode design save as much battery as pure "AMOLED black" in OLED displays? The results may surprise you.

Using dark grey instead of black for dark themes is part of the Material Design guidelines:

Material Design

Material Design

Build beautiful, usable products faster. Material Design is an adaptable system‚Äîbacked by open-source code‚Äîthat helps teams build high quality digital experiences.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
The material design guidelines seem to recommend dark grey for ‚Äúspace‚Äù, ‚Äúbackground‚Äù and for ‚Äúsurfaces‚Äù. Yet the guidelines do not motivate why specifically the background shouldn‚Äôt be black.

Use dark grey ‚Äì rather than black ‚Äì to express elevation and space in an environment with a wider range of depth.

Here the guidelines offer no explanation why the lowest ‚Äúspace‚Äù which isn‚Äôt elevated at all should not be true black.

Dark gray surfaces also reduce eye strain, as light text on a dark gray surface has less contrast than light text on a black surface.

The text isn‚Äôt displayed directly on the overall background, the text is displayed on the background if a message bubble, so there is no problem there. The message bubble is ‚Äúan elevated surface‚Äù and should if course be a shade of dark grey.
In places such as the settings where the text is displayed directly on the overall background surface, the font color can be dim white to again provide a non-eye straining contrast.

The most important benefit of a true dark background is that you can read in a completely dark room, or outdoors at night, while getting the least amount of dark blindness from your screen. All that dark grey surface area still emits a lot of light.

I hate how material design acts as an authority, but when you read it carefully they don‚Äôt really explain why certain choices were made.

Even Android Q itself uses true black as the background in the Android settings menu and notifications background, so it seems some designers at Google have realized that their predecessors weren‚Äôt always right on their design recommendations.

Material design guidelines are just guidelines, same as human interface guidelines form iOS. In the end it should depend on the designer and the app context what colora and shades are used.

With respect to guidelines for dark theme,

twitter.com

Steve Schoger

@steveschoger
üî• When implementing dark mode, don‚Äôt throw away the visual cues in the light version by naively inverting the color scheme. Close elements should still be lighter and distant elements should still be darker ‚Äì even in a dark UI. https://t.co/RNxgIppDmn
4:02 PM - 16 Jul 2019 10K 1.8K

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
Leptopoda:

IIRC Johan already has this functionality in his fork

Unfortunately this became unmaintainable for me due to frequent changes in the layout and I had to drop it. But for ideas you can of course always look at the source code in an older version (4.76.3.0-JW or older).

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 5.41 release

The contrast in the compose field is lower now. It‚Äôs harder for me to read, and I don‚Äôt even have problems with my eye-sight. I guess it‚Äôs even worse for impaired people.

I think they‚Äôre following material3‚Äôs guidelines for contrast. I noticed they‚Äôre sometimes lower as previous iterations of MD but I suppose Google‚Äôs designer must know what they‚Äôre doing?

PS: black (AMOLED) would be awesome for battery life edit: apparently that‚Äôs negligible.

posts.name: (he/him)
posts.cooked:
fossislovefossislife:

black (AMOLED) would be awesome for battery life

it‚Äôs completely off topic, but no it wouldn‚Äôt. #000000 hardly saves any battery over dark gray https://www.xda-developers.com/amoled-black-vs-gray-dark-mode/

and it‚Äôs pretty horrible from design perspective because you can‚Äôt really convey depth with it (no shadows on elements, for example).
